aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Analysis of Piper PA 28-235 in De Beque, Colorado
The accident occurred in De Beque, Colorado.
The accident occurred on March 14, 2014, at 17:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Piper PA 28-235.
The defining event was a low altitude operation/event.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Aerial observation.
The accident number was CEN14CA160.
The aircraft registration was N9172W.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The pilot had maneuvered at low altitude below the rim of a canyon in a remote mountainous area.
The pilot had performed aerial survey operations in the same canyon several times before.
During climb-out from the canyon, the airplane failed to achieve enough climb performance to clear the ridge.
The airplane impacted terrain at about 8,500 feet mean sea level.
The impact resulted in substantial damage to the airplane.
The impact caused complete separation of the left wing.
The impact caused partial separation of the right wing.
The airplane came to rest upright.
There was a significant fuel spill after the impact.
There was no postimpact fire.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.
The pilot reported that in the future he should maintain a higher altitude for flight over the canyon.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's failure to maintain control of the airplane while maneuvering at low altitude.
The National Transportation Safety Board found that aircraft climb rate was not attained/maintained.
The National Transportation Safety Board found issues with aircraft control by the pilot.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
De Beque, Colorado

## Date & Time: 
March 14, 2014, 17:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper PA 28-235

## Defining Event:
Low altitude operation/event

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Aerial observation

## Accident Number:
CEN14CA160

## Registration:
N9172W

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor

## Analysis

The pilot had been maneuvering at low altitude below the rim of a canyon in a remote mountainous area and reported that he had done this aerial survey operation in this same canyon several times before. During climb-out from the canyon the airplane failed to achieve enough climb performance to clear the ridge and the airplane impacted terrain at about 8,500 feet mean sea level. The impact resulted in substantial damage to the airplane including the complete separation of the left wing and partial separation of the right wing. The airplane came to rest upright and there was a significant fuel spill, but no postimpact fire. The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation. The pilot also reported that in the future he should maintain a higher altitude for flight over the canyon.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's failure to maintain control of the airplane while maneuvering at low altitude.

## Findings

| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |
| --- | --- |
| Aircraft | Climb rate - Not attained/maintained |

---
